41.20.text:
For every time we clapped our hands,
somebody somewhere in the world

44.39.text:
was injured in a car accident:
96 beats per minute.

48.24.text:
1.2 million people die
globally around the world.

53.05.text:
In Europe and the United States,
every year, almost 35,000 people

57.18.text: are killed in car accidents, on our roads.

60.76.text: Do you know what that is?

62.96.text:
Collapsing World Trade Center towers
almost every single month,

66.52.text:
and almost every single month
for the past 60 years at least.

71.18.text:
I can't be alone at thinking
that this is rather insane.

75.54.text:
we've accepted a status quo
in our societies

79.75.text:
I've decided to find out
why we've reached this point,

83.40.text:
what we could do to make
things better and think differently.

86.34.text:
Firstly, we have to look
at the streets themselves.

90.26.text:
For 7,000 years, since our
cities first were formed,

93.71.text: streets had a very singular definition.

95.85.text:
There was a space in which we transported
ourselves of course, but also the space

99.66.text:
in which we met, gathered,
talked to our neighbours, gossiped.

102.59.text:
Where we sold our goods,
where our children played.

105.28.text:
They were extensions
of our homes, of our living rooms;

109.17.text:
Probably the most democratic spaces
in the history of Homo sapiens.

113.19.text:
Now a lot of people seem
to have this perception

115.46.text:
that streets are the exclusive
domain of automobiles.

118.54.text: I discovered that two main things happened

120.55.text:
to cause this massive paradigm shift
in our perception of streets.

124.61.text:
Firstly, in the rapid urbanization
of the late 1800s and the early 1900s,

129.11.text:
engineers were
the urban heroes of the day,

131.17.text:
tackling any and all problems
that cities could throw at them.

135.27.text:
But when the automobile
showed up, people started dying.

138.50.text:
Nobody had a solution
to the traffic safety problem.

141.67.text:
So, almost in desperation, engineers
were handed the job, in collaboration

145.34.text:
with the automobile industry,
who saw an opportunity.

147.83.text:
But almost overnight, streets
became regarded as public utilities

153.03.text:
like water supply,
electricity or like sewers,

156.42.text:
puzzles to be solved
with mathematical equations.

160.07.text:
Secondly, the automobile
industry had a problem.

162.37.text:
they had products to sell
and yet everybody hated them.

164.99.text:
This was something
called the Anti-Automobile Age.

170.18.text:
The automobile industry
used techniques like marketing, spin,

174.57.text:
and good old-fashioned ridicule
to change people's perceptions.

178.02.text:
They started campaigns, for example
against what they called "jaywalking,"

181.75.text:
crossing the street
in the middle of the block.

184.28.text: Now, in the American slang of the day,

186.15.text:
a "jay" was a derogatory term
for a country bumpkin, a redneck,

189.89.text:
somebody who didn't know
the ways of the cool big city.

193.37.text:
People were ridiculed
when they tried to cross the street

196.09.text:
in the middle of the block -
a 7,000 year-old habit.

198.54.text:
Boy scouts were enlisted,
handing out flyers to these people,

203.12.text: Also, anybody who was against cars,

204.82.text:
they were labeled as old-fashioned,
standing in the way of progress.

210.19.text:
nobody in our cities likes
to be considered old-fashioned,

212.91.text: and nobody anywhere likes to be ridiculed.

214.95.text:
So, pedestrians were herded up
to the street corners

217.39.text: to use these things called crosswalks.

219.26.text:
Children were shepherded into these
newly invented things called playgrounds.

222.94.text:
Finally the streets were clear
of irritating obstacles

225.47.text:
and the stage was set
for the paradigm shift,

227.57.text:
probably the greatest paradigm shift
in the history of our cities.

233.55.text:
Welcome to the tail end
of 100 years of traffic engineering.

237.40.text: What do we have to show for it?

239.86.text:
Nobody's figured out how to make
traffic flow more effectively,

242.88.text:
how to ease congestion, or how to stop
people from getting killed or injured.

246.61.text:
Streets carve up our cities
like angry rivers slicing through sand.

249.87.text:
Traffic safety problems,
but also pollution, social exclusion.

254.76.text:
If you look at it long and hard,
we live in cities that are in controlled

258.24.text:
by bizarre, often outdated,
mathematical models and equations,

264.77.text:
Even lovely cities like
Copenhagen and Zurich.

267.62.text:
Sometimes it feels like we're all
just characters in the Matrix.

270.91.text:
Seriously, cities around the world
can't put in a simple decent cycle track

274.59.text:
or widen the sidewalks, traffic-calm
a neighborhood, lower the speed limits

278.21.text:
because it doesn't fit
into the mathematical equation

281.17.text:
on the computer
down the engineering department.

283.57.text: So many ideas die on their doorstep.

287.31.text:
Let me ask you,
is there a way out of the Matrix?

290.51.text:
Urbanization is on the rise
now more than ever before,

293.15.text:
and we need new solutions;
we need them in a hurry.

295.79.text:
Should we really be engineering something
as human and organic as public streets?

300.89.text: It's the people who define the city.

302.69.text:
Shouldn't we study their behavior,
their patterns, their movements,

307.24.text:
in order to figure out
how to further develop our cities?

310.97.text:
If you think about it,
it worked for about 7,000 years.

313.55.text:
I think there's a pretty good chance
it's going to work again.

318.03.text:
One is basic human observation,
something we all share.

323.15.text: But when you boil it down,

324.50.text:
it's just a simple act of people studying
what other people are doing: watching.

329.73.text:
the French philosopher Gaston Bachelard
described this idea of "desire lines."

334.18.text:
"Desire lines" is the most beautiful
expression in urban planning.

338.06.text: This is an example, from Copenhagen.

341.29.text:
This is a street corner on the busiest
bicycle street in the world.

344.72.text:
The city discovered
that a couple thousand cyclists

347.15.text:
were cutting across a sidewalk here
to get to a parallel street.

350.18.text:
Instead of handing out tickets
to them all day long,

352.80.text:
they observed, accepting the fact that
there must be a very good reason for this.

357.98.text:
A temporary cycle track
was put in to see how that went,

360.64.text: and it was finally made permanent.

362.44.text:
The subconscious desire lines of just
a couple thousand citizens were respected.

368.71.text:
This is the view from my hotel room
in Halifax, Canada earlier this year.

372.46.text:
Fresh snow on the Common,
the park in the heart of the city.

375.45.text:
The green lines are the original pathways,
perfect for 19th century promenading,

379.59.text:
walking your dog on a Sunday,

384.38.text: But the red lines show you

385.69.text:
where the people were actually
walking and cycling

388.08.text:
in the morning rush hour,

391.30.text:
carving desire lines straight

395.11.text:
A modern city would observe
and redesign accordingly.

399.77.text:
Desire lines are great;
we really love desire lines at my company.

403.38.text:
We filmed an intersection in Copenhagen
for 12 hours on a random day in April,

407.51.text:
and we mapped the desire lines
of every single one of the 16,558 cyclists

412.52.text: who went through there that day.

414.14.text:
That's not even a busy
intersection in Copenhagen.

416.74.text:
I can tell you
it was a fascinating exercise.

418.86.text: We had an anthropologist working on it.

421.16.text:
There's no mathematical model
that can replace

423.44.text:
12 hours of intense human observation -
actually it was probably 150 hours,

428.26.text:
but when you're studying and looking
for new innovative solutions

431.81.text: for our cities, which we are.

433.94.text:
In my work developing
bicycle infrastructure and bicycle culture

438.32.text:
I'm constantly amazed
and baffled and frustrated

440.57.text:
at how many planners and engineers
have never even tried

443.20.text:
to ride a bicycle in their city
or spend any serious time as pedestrians.

447.01.text:
It's all office work,
computer models, maps.

451.33.text:
This brings us to the second thing
that we need for modernizing our cities:

456.40.text: We all have a relationship with design.

458.29.text:
We all make design choices
every single day.

460.36.text:
It's a part of our DNA,
no matter where we're from.

462.76.text:
And here's the thing: a designer thinks
and works differently than an engineer.

466.55.text:
A designer thinks about
the end user of the product.

469.24.text:
That human being on the other end
of the design process is everything.

472.91.text:
They work with functionality,
usability, user friendliness.

476.02.text:
They work with concepts like
the four types of pleasure:

479.20.text:
physio, socio, pshyco, ideal pleasure
in everything they do.

483.30.text:
Designing a city for bicycles,
or pedestrians,

485.86.text: or any aspect of a truly liveable city

487.68.text:
should be like designing
any other product on the market:

491.03.text:
a toothbrush, a toaster,
a smartphone, a chair.

495.07.text:
When you all came in here today,
you found your seats and you sat down.

498.44.text:
You didn't have to take a moment
to contemplate the chair,

501.76.text:
interpret the designer's intentions,
figure out how to work it,

506.61.text:
You didn't have to worry about
whether it's going to disappear

509.52.text: from under you in the middle of my talk.

513.76.text:
That's how designing cities
for people should be.

516.11.text:
Imagine if riding a bicycle or walking
in the city was that easy or intuitive.

520.68.text: That would be cool, and it's possible.

523.52.text:
Design is a powerful and beautiful tool
if we apply it correctly.

526.93.text:
It can also be seductive, making us forget
about all sorts of other important things.

531.31.text:
80% of us in this room probably don't need
the smartphones in our pockets

534.75.text:
but my god we saved up for them,
and hurried down to acquire them

539.13.text:
Well designed bicycle infrastructure
will seduce people to use it.

542.75.text:
You make the bicycle the quickest way
from A to B in a city,

546.74.text:
It doesn't matter how hilly, how hot,
how cold, citizen cyclists will ride,

550.42.text:
seduced by the good design,
the convenience and the safety.

555.13.text:
Good design can also
improve human behavior.

558.37.text: I hear the same thing around the world,

560.22.text:
"All those damn cyclists,
breaking the law, running red lights,

566.19.text:
I have one response to that:
those cyclists do not have

568.92.text:
adequate bicycle infrastructure,
even worse, none at all;

571.62.text:
never mind the fact that they're forced
to abide by a traffic culture

574.88.text:
and traffic laws that were invented
to serve the automobile,

579.52.text: In Copenhagen, in the morning rush hour,

581.47.text:
when a couple hundred thousand people
ride their bikes to work, it's different.

585.99.text:
At every traffic light cycle,
you have great groups of citizen cyclists

589.68.text:
doing something really weird:
they're waiting for the light

592.51.text: to turn green, checking their smartphones.

594.97.text: They don't need to break the law

596.53.text:
because they're on a well-designed

599.34.text: and a whole network of it.

If you think about it, regular citizens

604.30.text:
They don't want to be the rogues

606.95.text: standing out like a sore thumb in society.

608.99.text:
They just want to go about
their daily lives,

611.24.text:
go from A to B quickly,
efficiently and safely.

614.29.text:
The good cities of the future
have to be based on human observation,

618.68.text:
and on design principles,

622.26.text:
and observations of the leading

I said, "Cool, maybe it's nice,
maybe they're friends,

Look, you and me,

676.15.text:
of two people doing this,

691.12.text:
the social exclusion

My kids spend about five hours

Lulu-Sophia has a brother;
his name's Felix; he's 10.

Earlier this year I thought
it'd be interesting

706.69.text:
to get his third grade class

709.67.text:
at the intersection by their school,

Without too much input from me,

doing site visits, talking to each other,

721.24.text:
actually only making drawings;

One of them was that they wanted

730.40.text:
and cycle tracks and sidewalks

734.98.text:
But apart from that,

based on human observation,

741.98.text:
If we allow ourselves to think

746.30.text:
Planning for intelligent transport forms
like cycling, like walking,

751.44.text:
The glass roofs were a funny idea,

753.95.text:
As we speak, there are cities

756.22.text:
who are installing rain sensors

759.21.text:
so that when it rains,
snows, or gets too cold,

762.16.text:
those cyclists are prioritized,

765.34.text:
getting those people home

In Copenhagen,
we have the green wave in place

772.60.text:
on several arteries

774.81.text:
20 km per hour, and you hit green

and all the way home again

782.85.text: All of this begs the question,

785.46.text:
"What would the streets
of our cities look like

788.32.text:
if our main consultants
were five-year-olds, third graders,

792.42.text: and teams of young design students?"

797.23.text:
They would certainly work better
than they're working now

799.94.text: and most importantly, they would be safer

802.08.text:
than at any single point
in the last 60 years.

805.18.text:
I'll tell you what's old-fashioned
and standing in the way of progress

808.51.text:
and that is engineering human streets
instead of designing them.

813.19.text:
But at the end of the day, this isn't
about bicycles and infrastructure,

816.67.text:
pedestrian facilities, urban planning,
urban design, livable cities.

820.72.text:
I'll tell you what this is;
it's bigger than all that.

825.07.text:
Monuments that we,
the people, design and erect.

828.08.text:
Monuments to liveable cities, to the past,
the present and all important future.

833.55.text:
Monuments that make cities better
and monuments that save lives

837.43.text:
instead of wiping them out
or destroying them.

843.10.text:
If you think about it,
we are the architects.

853.81.text: I want to leave you with this quote:

858.86.text:
Like giant mirrors, they reflect
the hearts of their residents.

861.81.text:
If those hearts darken and lose faith,
cities will lose their glamour."

867.21.text:
This is a 900-year-old quote,
more true today than ever before.

871.96.text:
And I ask you, is this
not the noblest of goals?

876.45.text:
We know how to do it to make
our cities and our heart shine.

881.19.text:
I think that we should just
take this paradigm and shift it

884.80.text:
back to where it belongs,
back to the future.

888.92.text:
I think we should let these monuments
to the future rise all over the world.

894.91.text:
Now you will clap again, but this time,
please don't clap for me,

898.03.text:
clap for shining hearts
and all the lives that we can save

901.32.text: and the cities that we can make better.
